prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: Once the Panel transfers actions to a single transferee court, the Panel's authority over the actions ceases. The Panel cannot become involved in any way in the proceedings in the transferee court and it is without jurisdiction to consider any matter concerning the handling of the cases once transfer is ordered.[1]

The transferee court has responsibility over all subsequent proceedings in the case until remand occurs.[2] For the purpose of pretrial proceedings, the transferee judge exercises all the powers a federal judge would have in actions properly filed in the district in which he or she sits.[3]

The transferor court exercises no further jurisdiction over matters pending in the case at the time of transfer, and need not decide any pending motions. The transferor judge is essentially divested of jurisdiction by the transfer order, and may not even decide matters previously taken under advisement.
Transfer does not, however, result in the consolidation of the transferred cases. Each case remains a separate action and may be managed separately by the transferee court.[4]

Because the transferee court's “jurisdiction” is limited to pretrial matters, litigants occasionally argue that it is not proper for that judge to rule on matters that may affect the trial. These efforts to limit the transferee court's powers are not well-taken. In one leading case, the transferee court established limits on the number of experts, despite the argument that only the trial court judge, upon remand, could enter such an order. The court stated:

A judge who has no power to impose limits as to what will happen at trial is obviously a judge who has little ability to manage pretrial proceedings in a meaningful way, since there would be no assurance that the judge's efforts are directed toward what is likely to happen at trial.[5]
The Factor VIII court recognized, however, that the trial judge has the ability to revisit or modify the transferee court's order in appropriate circumstances.[6]

In 2008 the Panel and the Federal Judicial Center published a guidance document intended to share some “best practices” for transferee court clerks. The document, Ten Steps to Better Case Management: A Guide for Multidistrict Litigation Transferee Court Clerks, does not impose any degree of control over transferee court case handling; it simply shares some collected wisdom about how the daunting challenges of managing complex cases can be handled by the clerk's office.[7]

The most current and informative work on management of complex litigation in the transferee courts is the Annotated Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth), an annually updated version of the Federal Judicial Center's Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth).[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Remand and the circumstances upon which remand occurs are discussed in Chapter 9. That chapter discusses in detail the fact that remand seldom takes place and reasons for that fact.
